articles.headline:
Britain to Halve 
Its Force in Iraq
articles.snippet: The move suggests that the alliance on Iraq forged between former Prime Minister Tony Blair and Washington is unraveling.
articles.abstract: The move suggests that the alliance on Iraq forged between former Prime Minister Tony Blair and Washington is unraveling.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Oct. 8 — Prime Minister Gordon Brown told the House of Commons on Monday that he would remove half of the 5,000 British troops in Iraq by next spring, and left open the strong possibility that all British soldiers would leave Iraq by the end of 2008.

articles.headline: Film Drop-Off Sites Fade Against Digital Cameras
articles.snippet: As another retailer, Stop & Shop, moved to discontinue film processing at its 300 stores last month, the nation’s new emphasis on digital processing is pronounced.
articles.abstract: As another retailer, Stop & Shop, moved to discontinue film processing at its 300 stores last month, the nation’s new emphasis on digital processing is pronounced.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fresh from a family vacation in California, Rick Wallerstein went to the Stop & Shop supermarket in Berkeley Heights, N.J., last month to drop off a roll of film, as he has done for about two decades.

articles.headline: Sallie Mae Sues to Force a Buyout
articles.snippet: The giant student lender is suing the firms that agreed to buy it, but are now trying to renegotiate the deal.
articles.abstract: The giant student lender is suing the firms that agreed to buy it, but are now trying to renegotiate the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: The SLM Corporation, parent of the student lender Sallie Mae, filed a lawsuit yesterday against a group of firms that had agreed to buy it for $25 billion but now are trying to renegotiate the deal.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: A Bank Bet on Condos, but Buyers Want Out
articles.snippet: Condo developers must begin repaying construction loans taken out before the market turned sour, but if buyers do not close, some lenders may be left holding the bag.
articles.abstract: Condo developers must begin repaying construction loans taken out before the market turned sour, but if buyers do not close, some lenders may be left holding the bag.
articles.lead_paragraph: Javier Miglin may walk away from an $80,000 down payment on a condominium with water views in Miami. Randal Mills may give up a $130,000 deposit on a 15th floor condo on the Strip in Las Vegas. And in San Diego, Jeanette Graham would just like to meet the neighbors.

articles.headline: A Settlement by Vonage Over Patents
articles.snippet: The Internet phone-calling pioneer came under fire from traditional phone companies that sought to shut it down, saying Vonage had infringed on their patents.
articles.abstract: The Internet phone-calling pioneer came under fire from traditional phone companies that sought to shut it down, saying Vonage had infringed on their patents.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vonage, the Internet phone-calling pioneer, has settled its patent dispute with Sprint Nextel for $80 million and agreed to license Sprint’s Internet-calling technology, the two companies said yesterday.

articles.headline: A Quest for Energy in the Globe’s Remote Places
articles.snippet: As global demand soars and prices rise, energy companies are going to the ends of the earth to find new supplies.
articles.abstract: As global demand soars and prices rise, energy companies are going to the ends of the earth to find new supplies.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMMERFEST, Norway — For a quarter-century, energy executives were tantalized by vast quantities of natural gas in one of the world’s least hospitable places — 90 miles off Norway’s northern coast, beneath the Arctic Ocean.

articles.headline: Aging and Gay, and Facing Prejudice in Twilight
articles.snippet: Elderly gay people in assisted-living centers and nursing homes increasingly report being mistreated.
articles.abstract: Elderly gay people in assisted-living centers and nursing homes increasingly report being mistreated.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even now, at 81 and with her memory beginning to fade, Gloria Donadello recalls her painful brush with bigotry at an assisted-living center in Santa Fe, N.M. Sitting with those she considered friends, “people were laughing and making certain kinds of comments, and I told them, ‘Please don’t do that, because I’m gay.’”

articles.headline: Stealthily, Stores Start Christmas in October
articles.snippet: Eager to expand the holiday shopping season, retailers are trying a novel approach: early advertising that deliberately plays down the tinsel and holly.
articles.abstract: Eager to expand the holiday shopping season, retailers are trying a novel approach: early advertising that deliberately plays down the tinsel and holly.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Stuart Elliott

articles.headline: A Senate Star Sparkles Less on the Stump
articles.snippet: Despite an impressive résumé, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. is struggling to draw crowds and coverage on the trail.
articles.abstract: Despite an impressive résumé, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. is struggling to draw crowds and coverage on the trail.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT MADISON, Iowa, Oct. 5 — As he strode into a coffee-and-scones meeting with the Jasper County Democrats the other night in Newton, Iowa, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. slipped off his suit jacket and unknotted his tie.
